data.title: Millikan, the First Physicist to See the Electron
data.meta_description: Millikan determined the charge of the electron by experimenting with a drop of oil. Although he did not believe Einstein, his results supported the theory of the photoelectric effect
data.text:
In 1923, the American physicistÂ Robert Andrews MillikanÂ (1868-1953) was awarded theÂ Nobel Prize for Physics,

“for his work on the elementary charge of electricity and on the photoelectric effect”.

In his Nobel LectureÂ âThe Electron and the Light-Quant from the Experimental Point of Viewâ he referred to theÂ experimentÂ that had enabled him determine the charge of the electron, leaving his audience convinced that he had seen electrons:

“He who has seen that experiment, and hundreds of investigators have observed it, has literally seen the electron”.

Quite often we physicists say that weÂ seeÂ those things on which we are working, no matter how small, or even abstract they may be. There is little doubt, however, that inside the apparatus used by Millikan there was a world of particlesÂ with which he became so familiar that he unblushingly claimed toÂ seeÂ things in thatÂ world.

Physics requires experiments, accurate measurement and, of course, conclusions to be drawn. There are numerous examples of decisive experiments in the history of physics. One of the most famous and important of these was that which enabledÂ the determination of the charge of the electron, conducted by MillikanÂ in 1909, which hasÂ become known as theÂ oil-drop experimentÂ or simplyÂ Millikan’s experiment. Indeed, it is considered to be one of âmost beautiful experiments in physicsâ and was pivotal in enabling the measurement of theÂ charge of the electron

Robert Andrews MillikanÂ was born in Morrison, Illinois (USA) on March 22, 1868. After graduating fromÂ Oberlin College in Ohio (1891) -where he particularly enjoyed studying Greek and mathematics- he did two courses in elementary physics, which awakened his interest in this discipline. In 1893 he was awarded aÂ fellowshipÂ at Columbia University, from which he received his PhD in 1895 forÂ a thesis on the polarization of light emitted by incandescent surfaces.Â AÂ phenomenon that had originally been observed (1824) byÂ FranÃ§oisÂ AragÃ³, Millikan used molten gold and silver from the US Department of Treasury to prove his thesis. After spending a year (1896) in Germany at the Universities of Berlin and GÃ¶tingen, he return to the United States to take up an invitation from the physicist and fellow Nobel Laureate Albert A. MichelsonÂ to become his assistant in the recently foundedÂ Ryerson LaboratoryÂ at the University of Chicago. He was eventually to become a lecturer there (1910), a post he held until 1921. In the course of his life (he died in 1953) Millikan was a Professor of Physics, Director of the Norman BridgeÂ Physics Laboratory and President of theÂ California Institute of TechnologyÂ (CALTECH).

A drop of oil to “unmask” the electron

Millikan was a key figure in the development of physics in the United States in the first half of the 20th century. If required to classify him as a physicist, his facet as an experimental physicistÂ would undoubtedly have to be highlighted, as would the numerous important discoveries he made, predominantly in the fields of optics and molecular physics.Â Millikan’s first great achievement was to determine the charge of the electron, to which end he used the “oil-drop method”.Â J. J. Thomson, the British physicist, had already established the charge-to-mass ratio of the electron back in 1897, but neither of them separately. Accordingly, if it was possible to determine one of these values separately (charge or mass), the other could be easily calculated. Millikan, with the aid ofÂ Harvey Fletcher,Â one of his doctoral students, used the oil-drop experiment to measure the charge of the electron (and with this, its mass). When Millikan began a long series of experiments in 1907, he had already been working at the University of Chicago for ten years, had got married, was the father of three children and about to celebrate his fortieth birthday. He had earned great renown as a physics lecturer, but had still not achieved anything noteworthy as a scientific investigator.

TheÂ fundamental electric chargeÂ is one of the basic constants in physics, consequently, its accurate determination is essential for this discipline. In his experiment, Millikan measures the electrical force on a small oil-drop that has been charged by an electrical field created between two electrodes when the drop was in the gravitational field. As the electrical field was known, it was possible to determine the accumulated charge on the oil-drop.

AÂ sprayÂ formed oil-drops, some of which fell through a small gap into a uniform, electrical field area space by two parallel, charged plates. A microscope made it possible to observe a particular oil-drop and learn its mass by measuring the terminal speed of its fall. The oil-drop was charged with x-rays, and by adjusting the electrical field, it was possible to get it to remain in repose, in static equilibrium, when the electrical force was equal to the opposing gravitational force. Millikan, carrying out a long and tedious task that involved a set of collateral experiments, repeated the experiment numerous times, eventually concluding that the results obtained could be explained if there was a single, elementary charge (the value of which he determined) and the charges identified were integer multiples of this number.

In 1909 he sent his first article for publication, in which he explained a technique he calledÂ “a drop equilibrium method to determine the charge of the electron, e”, entitledÂ “A new modification of the cloud method ofÂ determining the elementary electrical charge and the most probable value of that charge”Â .Â Millikan included his personal opinions on the reliability and validity of each one of his 38 observations. He marked seven “very good” observations with two asterisks, ten “good” ones with a single asterisk and left the remaining thirteen “satisfactory” ones unmarked. A genuine act of honesty, with respect to which the science historianÂ Gerald Holton would later refer to asÂ “a rather uncommon gesture in scientific publications”.Â In September 1910, Millikan published a second article in the journalÂ ScienceÂ about the charge of electrons entitled,Â “The isolation of an ion, a precision measurement of its charge, and the correction of Stokesâs law”Â , the first ever to fully explain his “drop equilibrium” method.Â Three years later, in 1913 Millikan improvedÂ the results obtained to determine the charge of the electronÂ eÂ =Â 4.774 Â± 0.009 x 10-10Â electrostatic units of charge (esu), i.e. 1.592Â x 10-19Â C (1 esu =Â 3.33564Ã10-10Â C) which is slightly below the currently accepted value of 1.602 x 10-19Â C, most likely because Millikan used an inaccurate value for the viscosity of the air.

An unexpected ally for Einstein

But this was not the only “crucial” experiment conducted by the meticulous Millikan. In 1905, in the course of hisÂ Annus Mirabilis,Â Albert EinsteinÂ published the article entitled,Â âOn a Heuristic Point of View about the Creation and Conversion of Lightâ. In this article Einstein theoreticallyÂ analyzes the photoelectric effect, convincingly introducing the concept of theÂ âquantum of lightâÂ (later re-named theÂ photon) and applying the ideasÂ Max Planck, before any of his colleagues had done so, to theoretically explain the photoelectric effect.Â Planck himself turned out to be one of the staunchest critics of this idea ofÂ light quanta, whileÂ MillikanÂ dismissed Einstein’s idea as a “rash, not to say foolish hypothesis”, quickly getting down to work on experimentally showing Einstein the error of his ways. After ten years of experiments (1916), Millikan published his results in the journalÂ Physical ReviewÂ in an article entitled,Â âA Direct Photoelectric Determination of Planckâs hâÂ .Â Nevertheless, and contrary to what he had originally intended, MillikanÂ not only experimentally validated Einstein’s equation for the photoelectric effect, but also determinedÂ Planck’s constant,Â h.Â The conclusion of Millikan’s 1916 article leaves no room for doubt:

âEinstein’s photoelectric equation has been subject to very searching tests and it appears in every case to predict exactly the observed resultsâ.

Nonetheless, Millikan intended toÂ demonstrate with his experiments that Einstein’s idea of âlight quantaâ was wrong.Â In an article entitled,Â âAlbert Einstein on His Seventieth Birthdayâ (1949), in the journalÂ Reviews of Modern Physics, Millikan wrote:

âI spent ten years of my life testing that 1905 equation of Einstein’s [the photoelectric effect], and contrary to all my expectations I was compelled in 1915 to assert its unambiguous experimental verification in spite of its unreasonableness, since it seemed to violate everything that we knew about the interference of lightâ.

On November 14, 1923 Millikan received aÂ telegramÂ from the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences informing him that he had been awarded theÂ Nobel Prize for PhysicsÂ for his work on the elementary charge of electricity and on the photoelectric effect, thus making him the second American to receive it. The text of the telegram reads as follows:

5 gs d 2625 803R

STOCKHOLMÂ 1030 AM NOVÂ 14 1923

DOCTOR MILLIKAN

PASADENA CALIF

NOBEL PRIZE FOR PHYSICS AWARDED TO YOU PLEASE WIRE WHETHER YOU CANÂ BE PRESENT AT STOCKHOLM DEC 10 TH

HOEDERBAUM, SECY ACADEMY OF SCIENCE

Millikan took part in the Third Solvay ConferenceÂ held in Brussels (1921) and wasÂ awardedÂ Honorary Doctorates by twenty-five universities around the world. In addition to the Nobel Prize for Physics, he was also awarded the Comstock Prize in Physics by the National Academy of Sciences, the Edison Medal and the Hughes Medal by theÂ Royal Society, not to mention a host of other honors.Â Millikan died onÂ December 19, 1953Â in San Marino, California, at the age of 85.
